content:
✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: It just how it should be for a clash: not too hard, not trivial, with a possibility to optimize solution length.
Nice problem for the Fastest mode, not sure about Shortest.

I inadvertently removed my previous comment.

Lemme explain what I said better maybe, you write:
"If Ataria starts near the top of the map and can reach the goal by traveling 15 steps East and 20 steps North, wrapping around to the bottom of the map(..)"

Now let's voluntarily remove parts of that that aren't relevant to my point, it becomes:
"If Ataria can reach the the goal by travelling wrapping around the map."
or even:
"If she can wrap around the map."

So... Can she? The statement doesn't state it clearly. It only is clear that 15+20 = 35.
Now then people will be able to get your meaning I'm sure, I know I did, but unclear statements are pains in my opinion because we get the hang of it quick then spend longer wondering whether we're missing something - because what we think isn't a full match to the statement.
So in its current state, this puzzle is a no for me.
Aside from that it's a good one I believe.
I think it needs coordinates as example in the third paragraph, or to be more clear about what happens, like for example mentioning in a single sentence that she blinks / teleports / appears / wraps around (works) on the other side when she reaches the end of the map on one side.
Cheers

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Good one!

Nice idea, but a confusing statement. For instance: "movement in any one of the four cardinal directions brings her back to the same position" from any point or from current/specific? I would make it reverse because from tests it's more clear than from a statement.
Very interesting problem, not too hard when you understand how to do it
OK thanks, I might give it a complete rewrite if I have time. It's considered a torus in the math world, but is there a more common word for this wrap-around behavior?

Oh, it's the "if" that threw you, with the wrapping all in the same sentence. OK I'll fix that. As to a numerical example, the third test case is titled "Example in Description". Should I move it to be the first?
UPD: Shortest was fun too, I quickly solved it in 100 chars in Python.

Now that you say it, this "if" is central indeed.
Can't expect a coder not to pay attention to ifs... :)

I'd say 1st and 3rd places both make sense for that "Example in Description" but I dunno.
Well I guess I'll go ahead and try that.

No, I mean I like the story, just don't use commonly used math terms like Totoid or cardinal, which here just confuse more than help.

I would say it like:  You're (or Ataria) in the magical world, where you can go only right, left, up, and down, and after going 100 steps in any direction you return to the same place. Now it's less confusing just because you don't have to explain "why" it's just what it is, because magic!
Awesome, thanks. Now edited. I'm avoiding "up" and "down" tho.
